snippet: When two people were killed and at least 23 injured Thursday after a driver slammed his car into a crowd, it crystallized the question of whether the South by Southwest festival has become too big and too rowdy.
abstract: Fatal crash at South by Southwest music festival in Austin, Tex, crystallizes question of whether festival has become too big and too rowdy, and lost original spirit of what it intended to be; two people were killed and at least 23 injured when driver evading arrest slammed his car into crowd.

byline.original: By DAVID CARR and MANNY FERNANDEZ
byline.contributor: David Carr reported from Austin, and Manny Fernandez from Houston. David Montgomery and Jenna Wortham contributed reporting from Austin, and Timothy Williams from New York.

lead_paragraph: When two people were killed and at least 23 injured Thursday after a driver slammed his car into a crowd, it crystallized the question of whether the South by Southwest festival has become too big and too rowdy.

headline.main: After Fatal Crash, Soul-Searching for South by Southwest
headline.print_headline: After Fatal Crash, Soul-Searching for a Festival

keywords.value: South by Southwest Music and Media Conference
keywords.name: subject
